author: Staff Reporter
text:
Members of the Cauvery Surplus Water Action Committee staging a demonstration in Salem on Monday demanding implementation of water schemes to utilise surplus water.— Photo: E. Lakshmi Narayanan

Demanding implementation of Thanadiyur – Moolakadu water scheme and Cauvery – Sarabanga river scheme, members of Cauvery Surplus Water Action Committee staged a demonstration near the Collectorate here on Monday.

The members said that surplus water from Stanley Reservoir in Mettur Dam was let into the sea every year through the 16-vent Ellis Saddle surplus channel.

But farmers in the district were unable to get water for agriculture needs and drought prevailed every year.

Survey

They said that the State Government had announced a Rs. 1,300-crore water scheme to benefit farmers in the district through which the Cauvery would be interlinked with Sarabanga River. The government had also allotted Rs. 50 lakh for survey works. But, no works were carried out.

They said that by implementing the Thanadiyur – Moolakadu scheme, water could be pumped and taken through the natural passage and interlink the Cauvery and the Sarabanga. Also, water from Sarabanga River in Omalur can be taken to mix with River Thirumanimutharu.

“These schemes helps in distribution of natural resources and remove regional imbalance,” they added.

Minister for Highways and Minor Ports Edappadi K. Palaniswami during his election campaign in 2011 promised to implement the water schemes after coming to power. Also, the then PWD Minister Duraimurugan in 2007 assured them to implement the scheme. “But none of the politicians took any steps for implementing the schemes,” they added.

The members said that over one lakh agriculture lands would receive water regularly besides recharging of groundwater level in villages across the area.
title: Protest seeking implementation of new water schemes
